'''Henry "Son" Sims''' (August 22, 1890 – December 23, 1958)<ref name="AMG"/> was an [[United States|American]] [[delta blues]] fiddler and songwriter. He is best known for his accompanist role to both [[Charlie Patton]] and a young [[Muddy Waters]].

==Life and career==
Sims was born in [[Anguilla, Mississippi]], [[United States]],<ref name="AMG"/> the only son of five children. He learned to play the [[fiddle]] from his grandfather.<ref name="AMG"/> Sims saw active service in France during [[World War I]], whilst serving in the [[United States Army|US Army]].

Sims went on to be the leader of the Mississippi Corn Shuckers, a rural based [[String instrument|string]] [[Musical ensemble|ensemble]] and played with them for a number of years. His profile was extended by joining his childhood friend, Charlie Patton, on a recording session for [[Paramount Records]], which took place in [[Grafton, Wisconsin]] in June 1929.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Gioia"/><ref name="Dicaire">{{cite book
| first= David
| last= Dicaire
| year= 1999
| title= Blues singers: biographies of 50 legendary artists of the early 20th century
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[McFarland & Company]]
| location= [[Jefferson, North Carolina]]
| page= 7
| isbn= 0-7864-0606-2}}</ref><ref name="Grave">{{cite web |url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=21866460 |title=Henry "Son" Sims |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Findagrave.com |accessdate=March 18, 2012}}</ref>  Sims both accompanied Patton on fiddle on thirteen tracks,<ref name="Dicaire"/> including "Elder Greene Blues", "Going to Move to Alabama" and "Devil Sent the Rain Blues";<ref name="Gioia"/> as well as recording four tunes of his own. These included "Tell Me Man Blues", his best-known composition, and "Farrell Blues".<ref name="AMG"/> Sims played alongside Patton at times until the latter's death in 1934,<ref name="Grave"/> when Sims returned to working on a [[plantation]].<ref name="Gioia">{{cite book
| first= Ted
| last= Gioia
| year= 2008
| title= Delta Blues
| edition= 1st
| publisher= [[W. W. Norton & Company]]
| location= [[New York City|New York]]
| page= 72
| isbn= 978-0-393-06258-8}}</ref> Sims had by then extended his playing repertoire to include the [[mandolin]], [[guitar]] and [[piano]].<ref name="AMG"/>

On August 28, 1941, Sims accompanied Muddy Waters on a recording session.<ref name="AMG"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cr.nps.gov/delta/blues/people/muddy_waters.htm |title=McKinley Morganfield "Muddy Waters" - Delta School |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Cr.nps.gov |accessdate=March 18, 2012}}</ref> This took place under the direction of [[Alan Lomax]], as part of his recordings for the [[Library of Congress]].<ref name="Gioia"/> In the 1940s, Sims also accompanied [[Robert Nighthawk]] on several joint appearances, and continued a solo career in to the 1950s.<ref name="Grave"/>

Sims died following renal surgery in December 1958 in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], at the age of 68.<ref name="Dead"/> He was buried in an unmarked grave in Bell Grove Baptist Church Cemetery, [[Clarksdale, Mississippi|Clarksdale]], [[Coahoma County, Mississippi|Coahoma County]], Mississippi.<ref name="Grave"/>
